note.p: Title with epigraph, “The Alps from Schaffhausen”; and title, “Entrance to Schaffhausen” (Poems [1891])—W. G. Collingwood gave the title “The Alps from Schaffhausen” to the poem that begins with the line, “There is a charmed peace that aye”, which is untitled in the MS VIII draft, the sole surviving text. He failed to signal this editorial intervention by surrounding his title with square brackets; instead, confusingly, in his reconstruction he preceded this poem with another, which Ruskin did entitle in MS VIII draft (again, the sole surviving text) as “Schaffhausen”, yet which Collingwood renamed “Entrance to Schaffhausen”. Collingwood did at least, in this instance, indicate his intervention by enclosing the editorial title in square brackets.

Collingwoodʼs rationale for his retitling is evident in the epigraph he added to [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”], which he took from Ruskinʼs autobiography, Praeterita. He expected the reader to approach the “Account” as documentary evidence for the revelatory Pisgah sight that structures the autobiographical account. As he commented in a note appended to “Schaffhausen” [“Entrance to Schaffhausen”], the poems are “worth comparing” with the autobiographyʼs narrative as “two accounts” composed “at an interval of more than fifty years apart, the one in verse and the other in prose,” describing the familyʼs first sighting of the Alps from Schaffhausen—the later prose version, he added, being distinguished by “a power of recollective imagination resembling that of Turner” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:283; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:285). (In the Library Edition, the quotations in Collingwoodʼs epigraph are dropped into notes [Works, 2:366–67].)

Ruskin does not explicitly identify the town of Schaffhausen in either of these poems, but Collingwoodʼs assumption is supported by the poemsʼ details, which, as the contextual notes explain, correspond to touristsʼs experience of Schaffhausen and its enviorons in the 1830s, as described in guidebooks and travel accounts, including the 1833 diary kept by Ruskinʼs cousin, Mary Richardson. More direct textual evidence for Collingwoodʼs assignment of titles lies in Ruskinʼs Plan for Continuation of the “Account”, which lists at least a section heading, “Schaffhausen”, but not Collingwoodʼs elaborated titles for the two poems.

If it is possible to situate either or both of these poems in Ruskinʼs Plan, they likely belonged under one of three proposed section headings: “Schaffhausen”, “The Alps”, and “The fall of the Rhine”. We have no way of knowing specifically where among these composite sections Ruskin might have placed these poems about Schaffhausen, if indeed he himself knew. It should be noted that the landscape feature to which he gives the greatest attention in >“There is a charmed peace that aye>” [>“The Alps from Schaffhausen>”] is the Rhine Falls.

But more fundamentally problematic about Collingwoodʼs titles is not whether evidence justifies them; it is his practice of reading the “Account” backwards from Praeterita that should be questioned. Collingwood wanted to document the experience as related in the autobiography, but such details as the cry, “The Alps! the Alps!” which appears in both the book and “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”], prove less that the recollected experience is accurate, than that the “Account” served as a source for the autobiography—and that, behind the earlier poem, stand the influences of literary and visual culture of the 1830s. See, in the apparatus for the “Account”, The Influence of Rogersʼs Poetry on Ruskinʼs Planned Extension of the Composite‐Genre Travelogue to Italy and Switzerland.

“There is a charmed peace, that aye / . . . / Sabbath noon was calm and cloudless” (MS VIII; Works [1903])—These opening eight lines in the draft of “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”] are omitted in Poems (4o, 1891), 1:140, and Poems (8o, 1891), 1:140; and the lines are restored in Works, 2:366.
